Issues.Title: [release/8.0] WinForms TreeView null reference exception 'owningTreeView'
Issues.Body:
Fixes #10876
Port of https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10880
(PR was created by cherry-picking commits one-by-one)

## Proposed changes
TreeNodeAccessibleObject can't be created when the parent TreeView is not found. This could happen when a node is being added or deleted from the Nodes collection. If AccessibleObject is not created on this attempt, it will be created on the next access. If TreeView is not available, we skip object creation. This fix was implemented based on the exception call stack from the customer.

## Customer Impact
Customer observes random crashes in their application when dragging TreeView items and clicking on TreeView subtrees with the mouse.
No workaround is available, 

## Regression? 
- Yes from NET7, introduced while enabling accessibility events to TreeNode operations.

## Risk
 - Low, we are exiting if accessible object can't be created. AccessibleObject will be created after the node is parented properly.

## Test 
- added unit tests
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10910)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "[release/8.0] WinForms TreeView null reference exception 'owningTreeView'" (#10910)

Issues.Title: no unicode characters with Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(True)
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

7.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The usage of `Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(True)` leads to a wrong presentation of unicode characters.

### Steps to reproduce

- put a button on the form and add a unicode character like a magnifying glass üîç to the text of the button
- deactivate the application framework in the project properties
- create a module with an own Sub Main
- set the start object to the module or the Sub Main
- use the following code in the Sub Main:
```
Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(True)
Application.EnableVisualStyles()
Application.Run(New YourMainForm)
```
- run the app

expectation: the magnifying glass will be shown as it is intended
fact: a placeholder/rectangle is shown instead

![Result](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/49878115/adc57ffe-55d0-4e04-8bed-5d7cb9258e50)

[WinFormsNetVB.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/14337379/WinFormsNetVB.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "no unicode characters with Application.SetCompatibleTextRenderingDefault(True)" (#10909)

Issues.Title: Input of thousand separators are accepted in NumericUpdown components even if ThousandsSeparator is false
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

8.0

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

no

### Issue description

We got a bug report about a user entering a comma in a NumericUpDownExt like: 

2,54651

and believed the comma was a decimal separator.

What he/she did not anticipate is that the current locale treats comma (,) as thousand separators.
What he/she should really input would be a period (.).


When the component was blurred, it correctly changed its text to

254651.000

But upon investigation, it turned out that ThousandsSeparator was false for the control.

Would it be possible to not accept the input of the thousand separator if those are turned off anyway?

That would cease the confusion (which led to the bug report).

### Steps to reproduce

Add a NumericUpdown in your form.
Be sure ThousandsSeparator is false.
You will still be able to enter the thousand separator character.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Input of thousand separators are accepted in NumericUpdown components even if ThousandsSeparator is false" (#10908)

Issues.Title: Add AppContext switch "System.Windows.Forms.ApplyApplicationFontToMenus"
Issues.Body:
<!-- Please read CONTRIBUTING.md before submitting a pull request -->

Fixes #10774 


## Proposed changes

- Add a new AppContext switch "System.Windows.Forms.ApplyApplicationFontToMenus"
- Add a condition in ToolStrip.cs to return the font of the form when LocalAppContextSwitches.ApplyApplicationFontToMenus is true.

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact

- The ToolStrip control font can be consistent with the Form by setting the property "`System.Windows.Forms.ApplyApplicationFontToMenus: true`" in the configuration file

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/132890443/46b7d36c-17dd-4e19-a221-574606168f93)


## Regression? 

- No

## Risk

- Minimal

<!-- end TELL-MODE -->


## Screenshots <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->

### Before

In 200 dpi mode, using `Application.SetDefaultFont(new Font(new FontFamily("Microsoft Sans Serif"), 8.25F, FontStyle.Regular, GraphicsUnit.Point, 0))`, the font of toolstrip and datagridview is different in Korean.

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/132890443/bbecf0e9-4bd8-4c33-8310-9b07ae26e353)


### After
In 200 dpi mode, the fonts of toolstrip and datagridview are the same regardless of the font used by the Form.

![image](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/132890443/9a8744cd-0464-4932-803d-fe12addca1f0)

Issues.Title: Adding Nothing to TextBox.AutoCompleteCustomSource stops app without any info
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 9.0.0-preview.2.24079.1


### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No, `The program '[23732] FrameworkApp.exe' has exited with code 3221225477 (0xc0000005) 'Access violation'.`

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Yes, this is not a regression issue, can reproduce from 3.1 ~ 9.0.

### Issue description

The app doesn‚Äôt respond for some seconds and will end after input the text for the textBox1. However there is no error message, exception or such a thing. And the user expect an exception message, like says: Adding null/Nothing to the AutoCompleteCustomSource is invalid.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open attached the reproduce application, then build and run
[FeedBack1949667.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/14320889/FeedBack1949667.zip)
2. Click the button1
3. Entering the textbox and typing any letter

**Actual Results:**
 The app doesn‚Äôt respond for some seconds and will end after input the text for the textBox1. However there is no error message, exception or such a thing for user.
![FeedBack1949667](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/assets/38325459/89c848cc-1b02-48f8-aa83-5df61df07f1a)

**Expected Results:**
Expect an exception message, that says: Adding null/Nothing to the AutoCompleteCustomSource is invalid.

Issues.Title: Improve data collection for unit tests
Issues.Body:
@sharwell had added screenshots recording for failed integration tests - https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10552 Add Window messages data to the test failure information.
However for some tests we could use additional information to identify causes of Assertion failures. We could start by logging windows messages:
 
 - [ ] Register a custom logger that would log all messages sent to the main test window and all its children with timestamps. Use DataCollectionService.RegisterCustomLogger to register the new logger. [winforms/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/IntegrationTests/UIIntegrationTests/Infra/DataCollectionService.cs at f8e6d3b434f6e58bdc5ec1900586071d17650cc8 ¬∑ dotnet/winforms (github.com)](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/f8e6d3b434f6e58bdc5ec1900586071d17650cc8/src/System.Windows.Forms/tests/IntegrationTests/UIIntegrationTests/Infra/DataCollectionService.cs#L13)
The custom log will be saved to the same screenshots folder. Our tests are very quick, we can start by logging all windows messages, logs will not be too big. We can monitor messages using a hook - [SetWindowsHookExA function (winuser.h) - Win32 apps | Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/winuser/nf-winuser-setwindowshookexa)
Roslyn repo implements custom loggers, can be used as a reference.

- [ ] once we start recording messages, we could log controls state (visible, enabled, etc) for the visual tree.
- [ ] Sam's suggestion: record state of the keyboard (to validate a theory that some tests are not restoring keyboard state properly)
- [ ] Sam's suggestion: _It might be good to have a CI variable that basically saves the APNG data for every test, including passing ones. This variable is always false by default, but at any time someone could queue up a run to effectively gather baseline data that can be used to cross-reference failures against what is seen on success._
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Improve data collection for unit tests" (#10902)

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/10894)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "More ThreadContext related cleanup" (#10894)

Issues.Title: Make IMsoComponent support opt-in
Issues.Body:
There is quite a bit of overhead on message handling and main thread set-up. Additionally it is non-trivial to follow what is going on when we process Windows messages. This PR creates two `ThreadContext` classes, one that supports `IMsoComponentManager` and one that does not.

Starting in .NET 9, you'll need to set the "Switch.System.Windows.Forms.EnableMsoComponentManager" switch to get integration with process registered `IMsoComponentManager`s.

Reviewing this should be done by looking at the individual commits.

Issues.Title: Revert "Move Mso code into a separate file"
Issues.Body:
Reverts dotnet/winforms#10884

Looking at this deeper I believe the better approach is to have two completely isolated contexts for everything outside of the message loops. The code is completely intertwined with the ComponentManager.

What I'm going to do instead is copy the full thing and collapse all of the disparate pieces from `ComponentManager` and `ThreadContext` into a single `LightThreadContext`. We can look at factoring the "shared" code from there.
